title: 115_hr6214
content: The Act may be cited as the "Paul Laurence Dunbar Commemorative Coin Act". Paul Laurence Dunbar, an influential African-American poet, was born on June 27, 1872, to freed slaves. He published his first series of poems at age 14 and became a prominent author by the late 1890s, with his work featured in major national newspapers and magazines. Paul Laurence Dunbar, a renowned African-American poet, passed away at the age of 33 in 1906. Dunbar High School, originally known as the Preparatory High School for Colored Youth, was established in 1870 in the District of Columbia, becoming the first public high school for African-American students in the country. In 1916, the school was renamed in honor of Dunbar. The Dunbar Alumni Federation, formed in 2002, provides scholarships and financial aid to students and graduates of Dunbar High School. The Dunbar Alumni Federation supports scholarship efforts, school and community activities, leverages the prestige of Dunbar High School and its alumni, promotes alumni from various graduating classes, finances student development activities, and funds faculty, staff, and parent appreciation activities. The Dunbar Alumni Federation collects artifacts and memorabilia from alumni to chronicle the school's history. The Dunbar Alumni Federation collects artifacts and memorabilia from alumni to chronicle the school's history. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half-dollar clad coins in honor of Paul Laurence Dunbar. The $5 coins will weigh 8.359 grams, have a diameter of 0.850 inches, and contain at least 90 percent gold. The $1 coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain at least 90 percent silver. The half-dollar coins will weigh 11.34 grams, have a diameter of 1.205 inches. The coins minted under this Act in honor of Paul Laurence Dunbar will have a diameter of 1.205 inches and be minted to the specifications for half-dollar coins. They shall be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The coins minted under this Act in honor of Paul Laurence Dunbar will have a design emblematic of him, with inscriptions including the year "2019" and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be selected by the Secretary after consultation with relevant bodies and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities during a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2019. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price based on the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales of coins minted under this Act will include surcharges: $35 for the $5 coin, $10 for the $1 coin, and $5 for the half-dollar coin. Surcharges received will be promptly paid to the Federation. This Act is exempt from certain commemorative coin program limitations and the recipient will be audited. The amounts received under subsection (b) are subject to audit requirements of section 5134(f)(2) of title 31, United States Code. SEC. 8. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary will ensure that minting coins under this Act will not cost the US Government and no funds will be disbursed until all costs are recovered by the US Treasury.
